By IRV NATHAN
Johns Hopkins varsity football aggregation, Middle Atlantic Conference champions, journeys to Westminster tonwrrow
to do battle with arch-rival
Western Maryland in an attempt to put the "icing" on a
highly-successful 5-1-1 record
"cooked up" during the 1960
campaign.
After Saturday there will be
no "tomorrow" for the Blue
Jays, and this is probably just
as well as far as Coach Wilson
Fewster is concerned. The team,
down to only twenty-five gridders, has been hampered by
numerous injuries accrued during the course of the season.
With the aid of Swarthmore
and a scanty win over Dickinson last Saturday, Hopkins assured itself of a successful defense of the Southern College
Division in the Middle-Atlantic
conference and took much of the
tension - out of tomorrow's clash,
Swarthmore's Garnets, beaten
by Hopkins the week before,
came through to upend PennThe Skipper finds a hole and heads for paydirt against Dickinson.

Musa Returns With Spouse
By BOB YOUNG
The News-Letter last week interviewed Mark Musa, just back
on the campus after an extended
honeymoon in Italy, following
his marriage this summer. Musa,
with his beautiful young wife,
Isabella, has taken up residence
in the basement of the Old
Dorms and is now engaged in
tackling the problems of perplexed undergraduates, along
with finishing work on his doctoral thesis, a critical edition of
the pre-Dante poet, Panucio.
Musa was born in Parma, but

shortly thereafter was taken out
of the country, finally settling
in Palisades, N.J. After his graduation from Rutgers, he studied
in Florence on a Fulbright scholarship and taught Italian at
Hopkins for two years, while
working under Dr. Charles
Singleton for his degree in Romance Languages. While an undergraduate at Rutgers, he did
translation of
excellent
an
Dante's Vita Nuova.
Having lived in the Dormitories in his first year as a graduate student at Hopkins, Musa

last year was made Dorm Councilor in Wood House. This year
he is a Dorititory Advisor, along
with Dick Barter.

the maintenance of the Gentle(Continued on Page 8)

Powell Announces
'61 Hullaballoo's
Colorful Format
George Powell, editor in chief
of the '61 Hullaballoo, announced
today that this year's edition
would contain "at least six single
pages of color" and would be
arranged in sections rather than
seasons.
According to Powell the '61
Hullaballoo will be at least as
large as last year's which was
272 pages and "probably larger."
Powell also added that he is hoping "to double ad income over
last year."
Rather than using the letterpress systeM of printing, the '61
book will be done in offset lithography which should give better
balance in the tone of the black
and white photos. The color
photos will be done in the four
color process which is the best
means of reproducing color on a
printed page.

SIR WALTER IIALEIGH

The Blue Key Club was formed
this year for the purpose of giving prospective freshmen guided
tours of the Hopkins campus.
The idea for the club origi-'
nated in the Admissions Office
last year. Previously applicants
had been interviewed by that
office, then given a map of the
Homewood Campus and told that
they could look it over themselves.
The Admissions Office felt
that some applicants did not
come to the Hopkins because
of the fact that they were not
given a tour of the campus, while
at other institutions they were
extended this courtesy.
Lickson stated this week that
the response of parents of the
applicants has been favorable.
"In several cases," he added,
"parents have admitted that it
was probably the tour that sold
them on Hopkins."

Cranberries
The Thanksgiving holidays are next week; midterms are over; the last football game of the year will be
played tomorrow. This is the eighth issue of the NewsLetter. Hopkins' year is underway again and, we fear, its
start has been an inauspicious one.
John F. Kennedy won an election by shouting "We're
standing still." He could have easily applied this to Hopkins' student leaders, but, if he had, we doubt that they
would have given him their votes. Some people believe
that the best thing to do is nothing. Might avoid criticism
that way.
But it is a fact that the holidays mark the first break
of this young school year and because of this we feel it
might be valuable to look at the beginning to find a direction for the rest of the year.

What do Hopkins men do in their spare time? Really
it merely depends on who and what they are. Mark looks at
his wife, while his wife gazes at an inverted cheerleader.
Some window shop on Baltimore Street; others prefer the
real thing and ask for Frankie. And when the pleasure is
over there may be a friendly visit with a Dean or two so
that their pleasant residence may be continued. And need
we add that there is always a spook present who needs no
diversion?

The Student-Faculty Camp gave rise to hopes that
the various student leaders were possessed of sufficient
interest and dedication to their jobs that the air would be
filled with new ideas and intelligent suggestions. Such
has not been the case as the only new idea seen at Hopkins
thus far was that of a, "Playboy Dance," and the worth
of that one is doubtful.
People at the camp talked about the "new" idea of
putting the SAC where it belongs, under the Student Council. But the Student Council gabs and gabs and gabs, does
nothing, and listens to one of its own members blast it
for not coming to meetings prepared to give intelligent
suggestions on the matter.
Last year, after two-and-one-hali years of trying, the
IFC finally straightened its own house by putting the
presidents orthe various fraternities on the Council. This
way, everyone thought, the IFC could at last do things
on a large scale—as made possible by the cooperation of
all the fraternities in common endeavors. So the IFC, the
first one to begin a year with the Greek presidents as
members, stammers through meeting after meeting, noting. this, then that, discussing beer kegs and rushing and
making people wonder: Was it worth it?
The News-Letter writes an editorial which points up
the need for getting, to work on the assembly program;
specifically, it asks that the University itself take a greater
role in planning the schedule and getting the people. So
everyone says: "You're right." The assembly chairman
of the Student Council resigns and a new man is appointed.
But do assemblies get scheduled?
The football team last year won not one but two
championships; but so few men turned out for this year's
team that one coach has intimated his fear for the future
of football at Hopkins.
The brightest freshmen class in history enters dear
old Johnny Hopkins, and the admissions office says:
"They're academically oriented." But they also say that
they are oriented to such an extent as to hamper their
participation in extra-curricular activities. As for the
future ...
We wish all a happy holiday and hope for better things
when we come back.

A Time For Spirit
Acting out of past experiences, Dr. Morrill has wisely
ruled that unescorted girls have no place at a Hopkins
athletic pep rally. The purpose of the rally is to spotlight
our championship gridders, and to indeed show them that
they are Hopkins' team. The show should belong to them;
but it won't, if dozens of unescorted girls are on the soccer
field, drawing all interest to themselves.
The time for cheering and support of the team is at
the pep rally; the time for meeting and dating is at the
mixer following the rally.

HOW TO BEAT THE BEAT GENERATION
My cousin Herkie Nylet is a sturdy lad of nineteen summers
Who has, we all believed until recently, a lively intelligence and
an assured future. Herkie's father, Walter 0. Nylet, is as everyone knows, president of the First National Artificial Cherry
Company, world's largest maker of artificial cherries for ladies'
hats. Uncle Walter had great plans for Herkie. Last year he
sent Herkie to the Maryland College of Humanities, Sciences,
and Artificial Cherries, and he intended, upon Herkie's graduation, to find him a nice fat wife and take him into the firm as
a full partner.
Could a young man have more pleasing prospects? Of course
not. But a couple of months ago, to everyone's consternation,
Herkie announced that he was not going into the artificial cherry
business. Nor was he going to stay in college. "I am," said
Herkie,"a member of the Beat Generation. I am going to San
Francisco and grow a beard."
Well sir, you can imagine the commotion in the family when
Herkie went traipsing off to San Francisco! Uncle Walter would
have gone after him and dragged him home, but unfortunately
he was right in the middle of the artificial cherry season. Aunt
Thelma couldn't go either because of her old leg trouble. (One
of her legs is older than the other.)

So I went. I searched San Francisco for weeks before I found
BeFkie living under theCounter of a Pronto Pup stand."Herkie,
how are you?" I cried, looking distraughtly upon his tangled
beard, his corduroy jacket, his stricken eyes.
:Teat," said Herkie.
I offered him a Marlboro and felt instantly better when he
took it because when one smokes Marlboros, one cannot be too
far removed from the world. One still has, so to speak, a hold
cm the finer things of life—like good tobacco, like easy-drawing
filtration, like settling back and getting comfortable and enjoying a full-flavored smoke. One is, despite all appearances, basically happiness-oriented, fulfillment-directed, pleasure-prone. ,
'Herkie, what are you doing with yourself?" I asked.
!`I am finding myself," he replied. !`I am writing a novel in
the sand with a pointed stick. I am composing a fugue for
Clavier and police whistle. I am sculpting in experimental materials—like English muffins.",
'And what do you do for fun?" I asked.
"Come," he said and took me to a dank little night club
Where men in beards and women in basic burlap sat on orange
crates and drank espresso. On a tiny stage stood a poet reciting
a free-form work of his own composition entitled Excenia: The
Story of a Boy while behind him a jazz trio played 200 chorusea
of Tin Roof Blues.
'Herkie,"said I,"come home with me to the artificial cherries!:
`'No," said Herkie, so sadly I went home to tell Uncle Walter
the bad news. He was less distressed than I had feared. It seems
Uncle Walter has another son,a quiet boy named Edvorts,about
Whom he had completely forgotten, and today Edvorts is in
business with Uncle Walter and Herkie is beat in San Francisco,
and everyone is happy.

1, 1960. The sums come from
the fines charged for each parking violation on campus.
The fines were levied to discourage parking violations, because the problem has become
SO serious. Car owners usually
have to park off campus on surrounding streets, while visitors
Often have trouble finding a
space. The Plant Manager's
Office is constantly considering
the problem in an effort to provide maximum efficiency in the
use of parking facilities.

have been issued to holders of
Parking permits to speed identification of cars on campus, and
Campus road. Parking lots are
Patrolled sixteen hours a day,
and cars not displaying a sticker
are ticketed or towed away.
Another evildoer pays the price.

men's Code in its traditional
form, is often visited by students
with problems, who see him as
the best person to see before they
get tangled up with the administration. The consensus of opinion in the Dorms is that many
undergraduates feel that he is
their last bastion against the
current encroachments upon the

traditional Hopkins freedom.
Musa revealed his theories to
the News-Letter: "I approve
highly of the Gentlemen's Code
in its traditional form at Hopkins. The ideal system is one
with as few rules as possible,
but of course, some rules are
necessary. Whether the present
body of rules in the Dorms is
necessary or not is a matter of
opinion. What must be avoided
is a system like they have at
Rutgers, where the dorms are
run on a lot of stiff rules with
practically no individual freedom. The Gentlemen's code in
its present form seems to me to
be infinitely preferable to such

a system. As for how to maintain the Code against encroachments, I would say that the best
way is for people to come to me
or Dick when they have a problem which they cannot handle
themselves. I would advocate
that the president of each house
try to solve all problems within
the house, rather than taking
them outside. If the problem is
too difficult to settle within the
house, then let them come to me
or to Dick. Meanwhile, in order
to be better able to handle students' problems, we (Barter and
I) hope, to meet as many of the
students as possible, especially
the Freshmen."

and 1434 are undergraduates.
Enrolled in the School of Engineering are 182 grads, 180 men
and 2 women. Of these 116 are
here on a full-time basis and
the remaining 66 are part-time
students.
The remaining 681 grads are
enrolled in the Faculty of
Philosophy Dept. This figure is
broken down into 585 full-time

men and 29 women.
The 1434 undergraduates are
separated into four groups: 285
seniors; 318 juniors; 402 sophmores including a number of
Poly A students; and 417 freshmen. The majority of the undergraduates, 865, are enrolled in
the Arts and Sciences Department: 163 seniors; 186 juniors;
234 sophmores; and 282 frosh.

FACULTY MEMBERS
Telephone engineer Bill Pigott, left, and helicopter pilot plan aerial exploration for microwave tower sites.

"I ENGINEERED MICROWAVE TOWER LOCATIONS
ON MY FIRST ASSIGNMENT"
When Bill Pigott knocked on the door of
Pacific Telephone, he had two big assets. One
was an electrical engineering degree from Seattle
University. The other was a craving to jump
right into vital engineering problems.
It was not long before Bill was exploring
Washington's rugged Cascade Range in a helicopter to find sites for microwave relay towers
—part of a multimillion dollar telephone construction job. Today, it's considerable satisfaction to him to see these towers spanning the
mountains, knowing that his planning helped
put them there.

Other important assignments followed: engineering maritime radio systems, SAGE systems
—figuring engineering costs for Air Force Titan
missile bases.
"Our people respect a man's engineering
training—you really get a chance to show what
you've got on the ball," Bill says. "I was up to
my neck in tough engineering problems right
from the start."
If you want a job where you put your training
to work from the day you hang up your hat—you'll
want to visit your Placement Office for literature
and additional information.(

"Our number one aim is to have in
management jobs the most vital, intelligent, positive and imaginative men we
can possibly find."4
FREDERICK It. KAPPEL, President
American Telephone & Telegraph Co.

Number Please S4 Sweep Around End
By PHIL BERGER
The unlimited role that telephone communications can play
in today's complex football game
was clearly shown in a recent
Sports Illustrated (Sept. 26, '60)
article:
"Seated high up in a pressbox where he had a better view
of the patterns and tactics of
the game than he would have
n
had at ground level, Orego
State's Coach Tommy Prothro
telephoned his instructions before each play to an assistant
on the bench; these were transmitted to the "wild card" substitute, who took them onto the
field. The upshot: Oregon State
defeated USC (an 18-point favorite by a score of 14-0 to provide one of 1960's first major
college upsets."
The Homewood version of
phone-to-field communications
is not as dominant as Oregon
State's. Primarily, it serves as a
complementary force, an extra
factor to supply Coach Wilson
Fewster with helpful suggestions.
The word "suggestions" shows
where Hopkins' system differs
with the "calling all shots"
method of Oregon State's Prothro.
The variations in the two
methods can be attributed to

basic differences in football philosophy. As assistant coach Ross
Sachs explained it: "we would
rather have the boys assume the
initiative. Our tailback (either
Henry Ciccarone, Joe Cioni, or
Skip Leet) calls the majority of
the plays. Coach Fewster will
send in plays only in key or
crucial situations. For instance,
in the Swarthmore game, I'd
estimate he only called five out
of seventy plays. Of course, depending on game and situation,
this figure will vary. However,
we do think it is a good idea for
our boys to call the plays. It
brings out the best in them."
The week before a game,
Coach Fewster will review with
his signal callers those plays that
should do the job against that
week's opponent. At half-time
adjustments are made in blocking assignments to compensate
for defensive shifts.
Hopkins' telephones work like
this: The assistant coach who
has scouted that week's opposition will mount the steps to the
press box of Homewood Field
and assume his position there.
Last week against Dickenson,
that man was assistant coach
Sachs. His Messages are relayed
from booth-to-field-to Coach
Fewster. The relay man is usu-

ally an injured player (in the
Dickenson game it was guard
Dick King) or it may even be
athletic director Mr. Marshall
Turner. In either case it is someone who is familiar with Hopkins' system. Coach Sachs explained that if he is not up in
the booth, he will be on the
road scouting a different club.
This rotating system allows the
coach who scouted the opponent
to look for flaws or patterns he
has noted during his observation
of that team.
Such knowledge aided Jimmy
Greenwood in his key interception in last Saturday's game, as
Dickinson drove for the tying
score. Sachs explained, "We
knew when they lined up that
they were in their favorite passing alignment. We hollered out
to remind Jimmy (Greenwood),
but he had already made the
he
proper adjustment, and
."
nicely
very
it
played

left and right formations. When
the Jays switched to a left formation the former Baltimore
Poly star failed to make the
necessary shift. With this valuable phone information the Jays
stayed in left formation and ran
wide to Foh's opposite side for
the touchdown and with the
same play for the extra points.
The variations in defense,
then, are the most import aspect
of telephone information. Anything else of value (injtred or
tired players, new substitute entering game, etc.) is also called
to Coach Fewster's attention.

In tomorrow's crucial clash
against Western Maryland, Hopkins will probably be without the
use of phones. Mr Sachs stated,
"Some schools provide them for
visitors, others don't. Phones are
available to all visiting teams at
Hopkins. I doubt if they'll be any
phone facilities at Western
Maryland. This could hurt us.
You can't say it'll be the difference between victory and defeat, but, invariably, it might.
They'll have a higher vantage
point and will be able to see
things that are impossible for us
to see at ground level."

Students Journey
To Special Confab
On US Problems
Producing informative discussions of the United States'
world problems and government, and broadening the student's outlook on national security are the objectives of the
12th Student Conference on U.S.
affairs at which Harry Lambright and Chips Lickson will
be representing JHU. They were
chosen as representatives
.because
they have the highest average
among Senior Political Science
Students.
The conference, which will
take place from Nov. 30 to Dec.
2, will highlight speeches from
the Hon. Nelson Rockefeller,
Governor of New York, who will
deliver the keynote address, and
Dean Rusk, Chairman of the
Rockefeller Foundation, who
will deliver the speech at the
closing banquet.
West Point
The conference will be held
at West Point. Representatives
from about 40 of the U.S. colleges and universities will attend with all their expenses paid
by West Point.
SCUSA, as the conference is
known, will consist of four discussion sections, each containing about 20 students and a
chairman who is an expert in
the field of the discussion. The
Conference sections for this
year are the Communist challenge, underdeveloped
areas,
the international community,
and building an international
order. The values of the conference, according to those in
oharge, lies not in the formation
of important documentaries on
the topics, but in the analysis
and understanding of the problems discussed.
Communist Challenge
Lickson, when asked to comment on his coming trip, said,
elily topic for SCUSA is the
communist
challenge. I am
looking forward to the conference in hopes that a way of
oombatting this very severe
Challenge may be found. Thereby, in future years, I may be
able to influence others on conquering the Communist challenge. and if not at least I'll be
More aware of it."

Cataloging Dept.
Cataloguing books in Sanskirt is just one of the problems annually overcome by the
cataloguing department of the
Hopkins library.
"We have seventeen members
in the department, many of
whom can read foreign languages. If none of them can
translate the parts of a book
which we need, we usually constilt one of the professors." But
this is just one of the problems
which faces the cataloguing department according to Miss
Jeanette Cabeen. Miss Cabeen
went on to add, "The cataloguing department is extremely
complicated and very difficult
to explain."
The system of cataloguing is
based upon that used by the
Library of Congress with adaptations suitable to Hopkins. Each
book is classified by subject. For
example, the subject of National
Conventions already has a certain number, and each new work
published on this topic is catalogued under this number with
respect to the author. It is the
job of the department to decide
under which classification or
number a book should be indexed. The department • also
determines what subject matter
(Continued on Page 6)

.Hopkins Magazine
"The Johns Hopkins Magazine" is perhaps one of the
finest alumni magazines in the
country. Since its inception in
1950 it has received three Robert Sibley Awards as the college or university "Magazine of
the Year."
Aside from its .circulation
among faculty members, graduate students and alumni in
this country, it can be found
in just about any country in
the world; in fact copies have
been sent to the library in Leningrad.
The magazine was founded
by Corbin Gwaltney, who until
1959 held the post of editor in
chief. The actual staff today
consists of Ronald Wolk, editor
and Anthony Neville, associate
editor. These two men, along
with their secretary, are responsible for turning out 6 issues a
year.
The purpose of this publication is not solely to keep alive
the spirit of Hopkins in its
alumni; it also endeavors to
stimulate the intellectual interest of its readers. The magazine
reports the research projects
and activities of all parts of the
university and presents articles
by members of the faculty as
well as by alumni who are doing interesting things.

I from "the Johns Hopkins Magazine" have been reprinted in
other publications. One such
article was reprinted in the
magazine "America"

By BOB YOUNG
The News-Letter last week interviewed Mark Musa, just back
on the campus after an extended
honeymoon in Italy, following
his marriage this summer. Musa,
with his beautiful young wife,
Isabella, has taken up residence
in the basement of the Old
Dorms and is now engaged in
tackling the problems of perplexed undergraduates, along
with finishing work on his doctoral thesis, a critical edition of
the pre-Dante poet, Panucio.
Musa was born in Parma, but

shortly thereafter was taken out
of the country, finally settling
in Palisades, N.J. After his graduation from Rutgers, he studied
in Florence on a Fulbright scholarship and taught Italian at
Hopkins for two years, while
working under Dr. Charles
Singleton for his degree in Romance Languages. While an undergraduate at Rutgers, he did
translation of
excellent
an
Dante's Vita Nuova.

he is a Dorititory Advisor, along

Cranberries
The Thanksgiving holidays are next week; midterms are over; the last football game of the year will be
played tomorrow. This is the eighth issue of the NewsLetter. Hopkins' year is underway again and, we fear, its
start has been an inauspicious one.
John F. Kennedy won an election by shouting "We're
standing still." He could have easily applied this to Hopkins' student leaders, but, if he had, we doubt that they
would have given him their votes. Some people believe
that the best thing to do is nothing. Might avoid criticism
that way.
But it is a fact that the holidays mark the first break
of this young school year and because of this we feel it
might be valuable to look at the beginning to find a direction for the rest of the year.

What do Hopkins men do in their spare time? Really
it merely depends on who and what they are. Mark looks at
his wife, while his wife gazes at an inverted cheerleader.
Some window shop on Baltimore Street; others prefer the
real thing and ask for Frankie. And when the pleasure is
over there may be a friendly visit with a Dean or two so
that their pleasant residence may be continued. And need
we add that there is always a spook present who needs no
diversion?

The Student-Faculty Camp gave rise to hopes that
the various student leaders were possessed of sufficient
interest and dedication to their jobs that the air would be
filled with new ideas and intelligent suggestions. Such
has not been the case as the only new idea seen at Hopkins
thus far was that of a, "Playboy Dance," and the worth
of that one is doubtful.
People at the camp talked about the "new" idea of
putting the SAC where it belongs, under the Student Council. But the Student Council gabs and gabs and gabs, does
nothing, and listens to one of its own members blast it
for not coming to meetings prepared to give intelligent
suggestions on the matter.
Last year, after two-and-one-hali years of trying, the
IFC finally straightened its own house by putting the
presidents orthe various fraternities on the Council. This
way, everyone thought, the IFC could at last do things
on a large scale—as made possible by the cooperation of
all the fraternities in common endeavors. So the IFC, the
first one to begin a year with the Greek presidents as
members, stammers through meeting after meeting, noting. this, then that, discussing beer kegs and rushing and
making people wonder: Was it worth it?
The News-Letter writes an editorial which points up
the need for getting, to work on the assembly program;
specifically, it asks that the University itself take a greater
role in planning the schedule and getting the people. So
everyone says: "You're right." The assembly chairman
of the Student Council resigns and a new man is appointed.
But do assemblies get scheduled?
The football team last year won not one but two
championships; but so few men turned out for this year's
team that one coach has intimated his fear for the future
of football at Hopkins.
The brightest freshmen class in history enters dear
old Johnny Hopkins, and the admissions office says:
"They're academically oriented." But they also say that
they are oriented to such an extent as to hamper their
participation in extra-curricular activities. As for the
future ...
We wish all a happy holiday and hope for better things
when we come back.

A Time For Spirit
Acting out of past experiences, Dr. Morrill has wisely
ruled that unescorted girls have no place at a Hopkins
athletic pep rally. The purpose of the rally is to spotlight
our championship gridders, and to indeed show them that
they are Hopkins' team. The show should belong to them;
but it won't, if dozens of unescorted girls are on the soccer
field, drawing all interest to themselves.
The time for cheering and support of the team is at
the pep rally; the time for meeting and dating is at the
mixer following the rally.

HOW TO BEAT THE BEAT GENERATION
My cousin Herkie Nylet is a sturdy lad of nineteen summers
Who has, we all believed until recently, a lively intelligence and
an assured future. Herkie's father, Walter 0. Nylet, is as everyone knows, president of the First National Artificial Cherry
Company, world's largest maker of artificial cherries for ladies'
hats. Uncle Walter had great plans for Herkie. Last year he
sent Herkie to the Maryland College of Humanities, Sciences,
and Artificial Cherries, and he intended, upon Herkie's graduation, to find him a nice fat wife and take him into the firm as
a full partner.
Could a young man have more pleasing prospects? Of course
not. But a couple of months ago, to everyone's consternation,
Herkie announced that he was not going into the artificial cherry
business. Nor was he going to stay in college. "I am," said
Herkie,"a member of the Beat Generation. I am going to San
Francisco and grow a beard."
Well sir, you can imagine the commotion in the family when
Herkie went traipsing off to San Francisco! Uncle Walter would
have gone after him and dragged him home, but unfortunately
he was right in the middle of the artificial cherry season. Aunt
Thelma couldn't go either because of her old leg trouble. (One
of her legs is older than the other.)

So I went. I searched San Francisco for weeks before I found
BeFkie living under theCounter of a Pronto Pup stand."Herkie,
how are you?" I cried, looking distraughtly upon his tangled
beard, his corduroy jacket, his stricken eyes.
:Teat," said Herkie.
I offered him a Marlboro and felt instantly better when he
took it because when one smokes Marlboros, one cannot be too
far removed from the world. One still has, so to speak, a hold
cm the finer things of life—like good tobacco, like easy-drawing
filtration, like settling back and getting comfortable and enjoying a full-flavored smoke. One is, despite all appearances, basically happiness-oriented, fulfillment-directed, pleasure-prone. ,
'Herkie, what are you doing with yourself?" I asked.
!`I am finding myself," he replied. !`I am writing a novel in
the sand with a pointed stick. I am composing a fugue for
Clavier and police whistle. I am sculpting in experimental materials—like English muffins.",
'And what do you do for fun?" I asked.
"Come," he said and took me to a dank little night club
Where men in beards and women in basic burlap sat on orange
crates and drank espresso. On a tiny stage stood a poet reciting
a free-form work of his own composition entitled Excenia: The
Story of a Boy while behind him a jazz trio played 200 chorusea
of Tin Roof Blues.
'Herkie,"said I,"come home with me to the artificial cherries!:
`'No," said Herkie, so sadly I went home to tell Uncle Walter
the bad news. He was less distressed than I had feared. It seems
Uncle Walter has another son,a quiet boy named Edvorts,about
Whom he had completely forgotten, and today Edvorts is in
business with Uncle Walter and Herkie is beat in San Francisco,
and everyone is happy.

space. The Plant Manager's
Office is constantly considering

Patrolled sixteen hours a day,
and cars not displaying a sticker
are ticketed or towed away.
Another evildoer pays the price.

men's Code in its traditional

with problems, who see him as

their last bastion against the
current encroachments upon the

traditional Hopkins freedom.
Musa revealed his theories to
the News-Letter: "I approve
highly of the Gentlemen's Code
in its traditional form at Hopkins. The ideal system is one
with as few rules as possible,
but of course, some rules are
necessary. Whether the present
body of rules in the Dorms is
necessary or not is a matter of
opinion. What must be avoided
is a system like they have at
Rutgers, where the dorms are
run on a lot of stiff rules with
practically no individual freedom. The Gentlemen's code in
its present form seems to me to
be infinitely preferable to such

a system. As for how to maintain the Code against encroachments, I would say that the best
way is for people to come to me
or Dick when they have a problem which they cannot handle
themselves. I would advocate
that the president of each house
try to solve all problems within
the house, rather than taking
them outside. If the problem is
too difficult to settle within the
house, then let them come to me
or to Dick. Meanwhile, in order
to be better able to handle students' problems, we (Barter and
I) hope, to meet as many of the
students as possible, especially
the Freshmen."

and 1434 are undergraduates.

here on a full-time basis and
the remaining 66 are part-time
students.

broken down into 585 full-time

men and 29 women.
The 1434 undergraduates are
separated into four groups: 285
seniors; 318 juniors; 402 sophmores including a number of
Poly A students; and 417 freshmen. The majority of the undergraduates, 865, are enrolled in
the Arts and Sciences Department: 163 seniors; 186 juniors;
234 sophmores; and 282 frosh.

FACULTY MEMBERS
Telephone engineer Bill Pigott, left, and helicopter pilot plan aerial exploration for microwave tower sites.

"I ENGINEERED MICROWAVE TOWER LOCATIONS
ON MY FIRST ASSIGNMENT"
When Bill Pigott knocked on the door of
Pacific Telephone, he had two big assets. One
was an electrical engineering degree from Seattle
University. The other was a craving to jump
right into vital engineering problems.
It was not long before Bill was exploring
Washington's rugged Cascade Range in a helicopter to find sites for microwave relay towers
—part of a multimillion dollar telephone construction job. Today, it's considerable satisfaction to him to see these towers spanning the
mountains, knowing that his planning helped
put them there.

Other important assignments followed: engineering maritime radio systems, SAGE systems
—figuring engineering costs for Air Force Titan
missile bases.

PAGE TEN

Number Please S4 Sweep Around End
By PHIL BERGER
The unlimited role that telephone communications can play
in today's complex football game
was clearly shown in a recent
Sports Illustrated (Sept. 26, '60)
article:
"Seated high up in a pressbox where he had a better view
of the patterns and tactics of
the game than he would have
n
had at ground level, Orego
State's Coach Tommy Prothro
telephoned his instructions before each play to an assistant
on the bench; these were transmitted to the "wild card" substitute, who took them onto the
field. The upshot: Oregon State
defeated USC (an 18-point favorite by a score of 14-0 to provide one of 1960's first major
college upsets."
The Homewood version of
phone-to-field communications
is not as dominant as Oregon
State's. Primarily, it serves as a
complementary force, an extra
factor to supply Coach Wilson
Fewster with helpful suggestions.
The word "suggestions" shows
where Hopkins' system differs
with the "calling all shots"
method of Oregon State's Prothro.
The variations in the two
methods can be attributed to

basic differences in football philosophy. As assistant coach Ross
Sachs explained it: "we would
rather have the boys assume the
initiative. Our tailback (either
Henry Ciccarone, Joe Cioni, or
Skip Leet) calls the majority of
the plays. Coach Fewster will
send in plays only in key or
crucial situations. For instance,
in the Swarthmore game, I'd
estimate he only called five out
of seventy plays. Of course, depending on game and situation,
this figure will vary. However,
we do think it is a good idea for
our boys to call the plays. It
brings out the best in them."
The week before a game,
Coach Fewster will review with
his signal callers those plays that
should do the job against that
week's opponent. At half-time
adjustments are made in blocking assignments to compensate
for defensive shifts.
Hopkins' telephones work like
this: The assistant coach who
has scouted that week's opposition will mount the steps to the
press box of Homewood Field
and assume his position there.
Last week against Dickenson,
that man was assistant coach
Sachs. His Messages are relayed
from booth-to-field-to Coach
Fewster. The relay man is usu-

ally an injured player (in the
Dickenson game it was guard
Dick King) or it may even be
athletic director Mr. Marshall
Turner. In either case it is someone who is familiar with Hopkins' system. Coach Sachs explained that if he is not up in
the booth, he will be on the
road scouting a different club.
This rotating system allows the
coach who scouted the opponent
to look for flaws or patterns he
has noted during his observation
of that team.
Such knowledge aided Jimmy
Greenwood in his key interception in last Saturday's game, as
Dickinson drove for the tying
score. Sachs explained, "We
knew when they lined up that
they were in their favorite passing alignment. We hollered out
to remind Jimmy (Greenwood),
but he had already made the
he
proper adjustment, and
."
nicely
very
it
played

left and right formations. When
the Jays switched to a left formation the former Baltimore
Poly star failed to make the
necessary shift. With this valuable phone information the Jays
stayed in left formation and ran
wide to Foh's opposite side for
the touchdown and with the
same play for the extra points.
The variations in defense,
then, are the most import aspect
of telephone information. Anything else of value (injtred or
tired players, new substitute entering game, etc.) is also called
to Coach Fewster's attention.

In tomorrow's crucial clash
against Western Maryland, Hopkins will probably be without the
use of phones. Mr Sachs stated,
"Some schools provide them for
visitors, others don't. Phones are
available to all visiting teams at
Hopkins. I doubt if they'll be any
phone facilities at Western
Maryland. This could hurt us.
You can't say it'll be the difference between victory and defeat, but, invariably, it might.
They'll have a higher vantage
point and will be able to see
things that are impossible for us
to see at ground level."

Students Journey
To Special Confab
On US Problems
Producing informative discussions of the United States'
world problems and government, and broadening the student's outlook on national security are the objectives of the
12th Student Conference on U.S.
affairs at which Harry Lambright and Chips Lickson will
be representing JHU. They were
chosen as representatives
.because
they have the highest average
among Senior Political Science
Students.
The conference, which will
take place from Nov. 30 to Dec.
2, will highlight speeches from
the Hon. Nelson Rockefeller,
Governor of New York, who will
deliver the keynote address, and
Dean Rusk, Chairman of the
Rockefeller Foundation, who
will deliver the speech at the
closing banquet.
West Point
The conference will be held
at West Point. Representatives
from about 40 of the U.S. colleges and universities will attend with all their expenses paid
by West Point.
SCUSA, as the conference is
known, will consist of four discussion sections, each containing about 20 students and a
chairman who is an expert in
the field of the discussion. The
Conference sections for this
year are the Communist challenge, underdeveloped
areas,
the international community,
and building an international
order. The values of the conference, according to those in
oharge, lies not in the formation
of important documentaries on
the topics, but in the analysis
and understanding of the problems discussed.
Communist Challenge
Lickson, when asked to comment on his coming trip, said,
elily topic for SCUSA is the
communist
challenge. I am
looking forward to the conference in hopes that a way of
oombatting this very severe
Challenge may be found. Thereby, in future years, I may be
able to influence others on conquering the Communist challenge. and if not at least I'll be
More aware of it."

Cataloging Dept.
Cataloguing books in Sanskirt is just one of the problems annually overcome by the
cataloguing department of the
Hopkins library.
"We have seventeen members
in the department, many of
whom can read foreign languages. If none of them can
translate the parts of a book
which we need, we usually constilt one of the professors." But
this is just one of the problems
which faces the cataloguing department according to Miss
Jeanette Cabeen. Miss Cabeen
went on to add, "The cataloguing department is extremely
complicated and very difficult
to explain."
The system of cataloguing is
based upon that used by the
Library of Congress with adaptations suitable to Hopkins. Each
book is classified by subject. For
example, the subject of National
Conventions already has a certain number, and each new work
published on this topic is catalogued under this number with
respect to the author. It is the
job of the department to decide
under which classification or
number a book should be indexed. The department • also
determines what subject matter

Aside from its .circulation
among faculty members, graduate students and alumni in
this country, it can be found
in just about any country in
the world; in fact copies have
been sent to the library in Leningrad.
The magazine was founded
by Corbin Gwaltney, who until
1959 held the post of editor in
chief. The actual staff today
consists of Ronald Wolk, editor
and Anthony Neville, associate
editor. These two men, along
with their secretary, are responsible for turning out 6 issues a
year.
The purpose of this publication is not solely to keep alive
the spirit of Hopkins in its
alumni; it also endeavors to
stimulate the intellectual interest of its readers. The magazine
reports the research projects
and activities of all parts of the
university and presents articles
by members of the faculty as
well as by alumni who are doing interesting things.

HKN Selects Nine
As New Pledges
After Interviews
After conducting interviews
on campus this week, Andy
Silinsh, President of Eta Kappa
Nu, the national honorary electrical engineering society, announced that nine members of
the Junior and Senior classes
had been pledged. The chapter
now has five active members.
The new pledges are: Seniors
Bob Walinchus, Gerry
Marty Lichtenstein, Sal Cuomo,
Pierce Smith; Juniors James
Fitzpatrick, P a u 1
Musicant,
Allen Layman, Jr., Bob Abernathy.
The pledging program is so
set up that initiation will take
place on December 18. Work on
an electrical engineering display
for National Engineers Week in
February is the project for the
pledges. Active members will
also work on the display.
